name: B. Mathematical Circus
statement:
A new entertainment has appeared in Buryatia a mathematical circus! The
magician shows two numbers to the audience n and k, . Next, he takes all
the integers from 1 to n, and splits them all into pairs (a, b) (each
integer must be in exactly one pair) so that for each pair the integer
(a + k)
cdot b is divisible by 4 (), or reports that, unfortunately for viewers,
such a split is impossible.Burenka really likes such performances, so
she asked her friend Tonya to be a magician, and also gave him the
numbers n and k.Tonya is a wolf, and as you know, wolves do not perform
in the circus, even in a mathematical one. Therefore, he asks you to
help him. Let him know if a suitable splitting into pairs is possible,
and if possible, then tell it.
editorial:
TutorialNote that from the number we only need the remainder modulo , so
we take modulo and assume that .If , then there is no answer, because
the product of the numbers in each pair must be divisible by , that is,
the product of all numbers from to must be divisible by , but the degree
of occurrence of in this sum is , which is less than .If or , then we
will make all pairs of the form , where is odd. Then will be even in
each pair, since and are odd, and since is also even, the product will
be divisible by . , then we will do the same splitting into pairs, but
in all pairs where is not divisible by , we will swap the numbers (that
is, we will make and ). Then in pairs where , is divisible by (therefore
the product too), and in the rest is divisible by (since and have a
remainder modulo ).The complexity of the solution is .
hint: Hint 1 Instead of , we can consider the remainder of dividing by 4.
Hint 2 There is no answer for the remainder 0.
Hint 3 For all other remainders, there is an answer.
